instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight, Im stumped.
threads.message:
Im getting a short every time I plug in the screen, my first suspect was <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>, however I have already replaced it and everything measures correctly.  <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.2V, same with <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST</SIGNAL>, its at 3.2V as well.

When I plug in the screen <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> gets 0V, and <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> gets shorted somehow. PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET goes to 1V, on F7700, and on <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> (Pin 4) and <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR>, and <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR>.

By the way <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 8.6V, but goes to 1V on PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET

When the screen is unplugged I get 8.6V on F7700, and 8.6V on PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET. <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> does not open of course but then there is 8V on <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL>.

Resistance of <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> are correct

I have already replaced <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> (Twice) and <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight, Im stumped.
threads.message:
Did you check diode mode at K/<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> w/ and w/o LCD connected?

"By the way <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 8.6V, but goes to 1V on PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET"
Bad F7700.
How can you think a good fuse has different voltage on its pins?

"When the screen is unplugged...."
What you expect to get then?
Any voltage measured is nonsense in such case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight, Im stumped.
threads.message:
F7700 turns to 8V (G3H and PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET) when screen is unplugged. Its a changed fuse as well, and is not blown.

<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> diode mode measures (red probe at ground)  measures 0.520V (without screen plugged in and with screen plugged in)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight, Im stumped.
threads.message:
Do you have same voltage on both pins of F7700, w/ and w/o LCD connected???

"<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> diode mode..."
Which pin???
I was asking about its cathode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight, Im stumped.
threads.message:
It was the fuse! You were right! It was trolling me, I normally measure if fuses are good or bad with resistance, however when i checked continuity through it, no beep, so thank you!

However another thing is wrong, I get backlight however on only half of the screen, tested on 2 good screens and both have the same issue. <RESISTOR>R7720</RESISTOR> - <RESISTOR>R7722</RESISTOR> both measure 0V when should be 14V correct? This has to be <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight, Im stumped.
threads.message:
"should be 14V"
Why do you suppose that???

Check if all return resistors are good and post diode mode to ground on them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight, Im stumped.
threads.message:
On a working board it was 14V on LED Return. Replaced <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>, works now.

Thanks!
